summary: This is a legal filing by victims Jane Doe #1 and Jane Doe #2 in response to the U.S. Government's notice regarding an evidentiary hearing. The victims argue that the Government violated their rights under the Crime Victims' Rights Act (CVRA) by entering into a confidential Non-Prosecution Agreement with Jeffrey Epstein in September 2007 without conferring with them. They request the court to order production of the agreement and an FBI interview report, and to find that their rights were violated. This is a legal filing (Document 19) from the civil case 9:08-cv-80736-KAM, submitted by attorneys for Jane Doe #1 and Jane Doe #2. It argues the U.S. Government violated the Crime Victims' Rights Act (CVRA) by not conferring with the victims during the negotiation of a Non-Prosecution Agreement with Jeffrey Epstein. The filing requests the court to order the government to produce the full agreement and an FBI interview report, declare the rights violation, and schedule a hearing on remedies.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The defendant in a pending federal criminal action; the party who entered into a Non-Prosecution Agreement with the government, which is the central subject of this victims' rights litigation.

persons.name: Jane Doe #1
persons.context: A victim in the Epstein case who was interviewed by the FBI on or about October 26, 2007. She is petitioning the court for her rights under the CVRA, including access to her FBI interview report and the Non-Prosecution Agreement.

persons.name: Jane Doe #2
persons.context: A victim in the Epstein case, joining Jane Doe #1 in petitioning the court for a declaration that the government violated their CVRA rights by not conferring with them during the plea negotiation process.

persons.name: Bradley Edwards
persons.context: The attorney representing Jane Doe #1 and Jane Doe #2. He communicated with the U.S. Attorney's Office, sent a letter urging federal prosecution, and learned of the Non-Prosecution Agreement only after it was filed in court.

persons.name: AUSA Villafana
persons.context: An Assistant U.S. Attorney involved in the Epstein case who secured pro bono counsel for Jane Doe #1 and communicated with victims' attorney Bradley Edwards.

persons.name: Meg Garvin
persons.role: Attorney, National Crime Victims' Law Institute
persons.context: An attorney with the National Crime Victims' Law Institute who was contacted by AUSA Villafana to secure pro bono counsel for Jane Doe #1, but was not advised about the Non-Prosecution Agreement.

persons.name: Brad Edwards
persons.context: Lead attorney filing this document on behalf of Jane Doe #1 and Jane Doe #2. He signed and certified the filing.

persons.name: Paul G. Cassel
persons.context: Co-counsel for the victims, admitted pro hac vice, listed as an attorney on the filing.

connections.description: Epstein committed federal sex crimes against Jane Doe #1 while she was a minor.
Epstein committed federal sex crimes against Jane Doe #2 while she was a minor.
Edwards is the attorney representing Jane Doe #1 in the legal proceedings regarding the violation of her rights under the CVRA.
Edwards is the attorney representing Jane Doe #2 in the legal proceedings regarding the violation of her rights under the CVRA.
They communicated regarding the Epstein case, with Villafana representing the Government and Edwards representing the victims.
Villafana contacted Garvin to secure pro bono counsel for Jane Doe #1, but did not disclose the Non-Prosecution Agreement.
Edwards is the filing attorney representing Jane Doe #1 as a petitioner in this civil action.
Edwards is the filing attorney representing Jane Doe #2 as a petitioner in this civil action.
Cassel is co-counsel representing Jane Doe #1 as a petitioner in this civil action.
Cassel is co-counsel representing Jane Doe #2 as a petitioner in this civil action.

events.title: FBI Investigation Opened
events.description: At the request of the Palm Beach Police Department, the FBI opened an investigation into allegations that Jeffrey Epstein used interstate commerce to induce minors into prostitution.

events.title: Non-Prosecution Agreement Signed
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida entered into a Non-Prosecution Agreement with Jeffrey Epstein, blocking federal prosecution in favor of state prosecution, and containing a confidentiality provision.

events.title: FBI Meeting with Jane Doe #1
events.description: FBI Special Agents met with Jane Doe #1 at a restaurant. They discussed possible resolutions but, due to confidentiality, did not disclose that a Non-Prosecution Agreement had been finalized.

events.title: FBI Letters to Victims
events.description: Jane Doe #1 and Jane Doe #2 received letters from the FBI stating the case was 'currently under investigation,' despite the Non-Prosecution Agreement having been concluded months earlier.

events.title: Edwards' Letter to AUSA
events.description: Attorney Bradley Edwards sent a letter to AUSA Villafana urging the filing of federal charges against Epstein, unaware that the Non-Prosecution Agreement already existed.

events.title: First Disclosure of Agreement to Victims
events.description: The Government filed a responsive pleading that first publicly mentioned the Non-Prosecution Agreement. AUSA Villafana also sent a victim notification to Jane Doe #1 via her attorney, explaining some terms.

events.title: Court Hearing on Emergency Motion
events.description: The court held a hearing on the victims' emergency motion. The Government discussed provisions of the Non-Prosecution Agreement in open court.

events.title: Epstein Files Motion for Stay
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein filed a motion to stay the civil action, claiming it was a counterpart to a pending federal criminal action, a claim the victims argue is based on the undisclosed Non-Prosecution Agreement.

events.title: FBI Interview with Jane Doe #1
events.description: Two named FBI agents met with Jane Doe #1 for an interview. The government has a report of this interview but has declined to produce it to her.

events.title: Filing of Victims' Rights Motion
events.description: Attorneys for Jane Doe #1 and Jane Doe #2 file this document (No. 19) with the court, formally requesting relief for CVRA violations, including production of the Non-Prosecution Agreement and the FBI interview report.

locations: Hollywood, Florida 33020 (address of Brad Edwards' law office)
Salt Lake City, UT 84112 (address of Paul G. Cassel)
Miami, Florida 33132 (address of the Assistant U.S. Attorney)
keyFacts: The U.S. Attorney's Office entered into a Non-Prosecution Agreement with Jeffrey Epstein in September 2007, which contained an 'express confidentiality provision' preventing disclosure to victims.

The victims, Jane Doe #1 and Jane Doe #2, were not informed of the agreement for approximately nine months, during which time they received communications indicating the federal investigation was ongoing.
The victims argue the confidentiality provision prevented the Government from fulfilling its duty to 'confer' with them under the Crime Victims' Rights Act (CVRA), violating their rights.
The Government has refused to provide the victims with a copy of the full Non-Prosecution Agreement or an FBI report of interview from October 26, 2007, with Jane Doe #1.
The agreement reportedly contains provisions affecting the civil liability of Epstein for crimes against the victims, which the victims need to see to potentially benefit from or understand.

The U.S. Government negotiated a Non-Prosecution Agreement with Jeffrey Epstein without conferring with the victims, Jane Doe #1 and Jane Doe #2, which they argue violates the Crime Victims' Rights Act (CVRA).
The government possesses an FBI interview report from an October 26, 2007, meeting with Jane Doe #1 but has refused to provide her with a copy, despite her rights as a victim.

The victims are not seeking to invalidate the Non-Prosecution Agreement but are asking the court to declare their rights were violated, order production of the agreement and the interview report, and schedule a hearing on an appropriate remedy.
Jeffrey Epstein attempted to use the existence of the secret Non-Prosecution Agreement to his advantage by filing a motion to stay the civil case on July 25, 2008.
This filing reveals an early legal battle over victim transparency and government accountability in the Epstein case, predating his 2008 plea deal becoming widely known.
